App description:
The most popular haunted house in VR is now available on Quest!

BE WARNED: This is not a game...but if you love to scare yourself witless, or just enjoy watching your friends and family freak out in VR, AFFECTED: The Manor is for you! With simple controls and no puzzles to solve or keys to find in order to progress, The Manor holds nothing but scares and screams for both experienced gamers and newcomers alike.

Built from the ground up for Quest, we've added a new terrifying layer of immersion by allowing interactions with some of the environment in AFFECTED: The Manor for the very first time. Weve made sure we maintained the trademark length of the experience, so each route can be tackled in around 20 minutes by anyone brave enough to make it all the way, plenty of Nopers out there are still yet to reach the end at alllet alone make it in one go! 

With a choice of 2 routes and alternate endings, theres reasons to return to The Manor...if youre a sucker for punishment of course.

Haunted House Simulator

This is one of a handful of games I use to show off the Oculus Quest to people for the first time and it's really entertaining in a group setting just to watch someone play and laugh at their reactions.

The setting is a classic victorian haunted house. Objects move on their own, doors open and slam behind you, ghosts make an appearance, etc. The graphics are quite good in terms of what the Quest is capable of. The visuals can look a bit muddy or grainy because of the dark setting, but the last update seems to have boosted the brightness and improved this substantially.

It's basically a haunted house simulator. It's not really a game as much as it is an experience. In terms of scariness, there were a few jump scares that got me but they are fairly spaced out. I would say they could have crammed more scares in but I've also seen many people refuse to play more than a few minutes.

You use the joysticks to move around and motion to aim the flashlight and open doors. This makes it very easy for a beginner to jump in, although the free locomotion may set off some people more sensitive to motion sickness. It is mostly linear except a couple points where the path branches. If you run through the game, it's about 15 minutes or so, but if you take every path that's 4 playthroughs.

That's not even counting the update that just came out with the new "Gauntlet" mode where you speedrun through a course while dodging objects that try and block your way. It takes about 3 or 4 minutes and it is not just running through the same pathways as the main game, this is a new environment with some new elements.

At 10 bucks it's worth it I would say. If you've played the game on other platforms, know that this version was built from the ground up for Quest and offers a different experience than the Go or PSVR/PC version.

The Best VR Haunted House

This is the third platform I've experienced The Manor on, I also have it for Go and PlayStation VR. The fact that several other reviewers have purchased this multiple times should give you an indication of how highly it's regarded.

Affected: The Manor is like owning your own Halloween attraction. It's a walk through a haunted mansion with multiple paths to the end, not a horror adventure game. How long each path takes depends on how long you spend cowering in the dimly lit corridors gathering the strength of will to slowly open the next door.

I've only gone through one path so far but I can say that It's easily the best version I've played. Most of it was all new, and the situations that were familiar were so much better than in the Go or PSVR version. It's the best VR haunted house I've ever experienced. Unlike the Go and PSVR versions you can now interact with objects and open doors. (I hope the developers update this to use hand tracking. Maybe you could point with a finger to move forward?)

The art direction and design are top notch all the way through. As to be expected the limitations of the Quest's processing power can be seen but there are some areas that rival PlayStation VR quality. The developers are pushing the Quest hard.

I'd like to address the complaint other reviewers have about the graphics smearing in dark areas. This seems to be a hardware issue and other games on the Quest with dark areas suffer from it. For example the dark areas in Star Wars Vader Immortal smear and blur as you look around. My guess is that the only thing the developers could do to address this would be to turn up the brightness, which would be a shame. Haunted mansions should be dimly lit.

The technical issue I hope the developers do look into is the movement. If you lean towards something to get a closer look it often knocks you back, breaking the immersion. The developers have already released a patch that addresses complaints about turning, so they're responsive to user feedback. (I just stand and turn around to navigate the Mansion. That's one of the perks of untethered VR, no smooth or click turning necessary.)

As much as I love VR horror, I would not recommend this or any other horror title for introducing people to VR for the first time. It would be the equivalent of introducing someone to hot sauces with a bottle of ghost pepper sauce. VR horror can be a very unpleasant experience for some people.

For anyone who has some experience with VR and is interested in horror, this is a must buy.
